required_header.download_date: Information obtained from ClinicalTrials.gov on October 20, 2011
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Computer-Guided Glucose Management Systems in Treating Patients With Hyperglycemia Who Have Undergone Blood and Bone Marrow Transplant
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Computer-Guided Glucose Management Systems for Patients Undergoing Blood and Marrow Transplants (BMT)

brief_summary.textblock:
RATIONALE: A computer-guided glucose management system may help manage glucose levels in patients who have undergone blood or bone marrow transplant.
PURPOSE: This clinical trial is studying computer-guided glucose management systems in treating patients with hyperglycemia who have undergone blood and bone marrow transplant.

detailed_description.textblock:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To determine whether using CGGMS algorithms in non-critically ill BMT adult (age >= 18 years) patients, can control glucose within or close to current University of Washington Medical Center (UWMC) intensive care unit (ICU) targets.
SECONDARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To compare two different CGGMS tools to see which reaches glycemic targets and which receives better nursing satisfaction.
OUTLINE:
Patients are assigned to 1 of 2 groups.
GROUP I: Patients receive blood glucose management with IV insulin using EndoTool.
GROUP II: Patients receive blood glucose management with IV insulin using Glucommander.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Supportive Care

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of glucose values within target range (101-150) with a given CGGMS

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of patients who experience hypoglycemia (defined as at least one blood glucose value < 70)
Percentage of patients who experience severe hypoglycemia (defined as at least one blood glucose value < 40)
Percentage of patients who experience hyperglycemia(defined as at least one blood glucose value > 200) 24 hours after initiation of infusion
Percentage of patients who experience severe hyperglycemia (defined as at least one blood glucose value > 300) 24 hours after initiation of infusion
Number of values > 200 or < 70 per patient per day of treatment.
Glucose variability (defined as standard deviation of individual blood glucose values)
Nursing satisfaction evaluated by a survey

arm_group.description: GROUP I: Patients receive blood glucose management with IV insulin using EndoTool. GROUP II: Patients receive blood glucose management with IV insulin using Glucommander.

intervention.description: Insulin rate is adjusted according to the software algorithms.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Post-transplant patients on the BMT Service at UWMC
- Expected length of stay > 7 days
- Requiring insulin secondary to: known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus; two blood sugar values > 180 (point of care and/or am lab glycemia)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Critically ill patients (ICU admissions)
- Terminally ill patients
- Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status > 3
- Previous type 1 diabetes mellitus
- Cognitively impaired patients, unable to consent
- Women of childbearing potential not on 2 different forms of contraception

facility.name: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center/University of Washington Cancer Consortium

responsible_party.organization: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center/University of Washington Cancer Consortium

condition_browse.mesh_term: Leukemia, Myeloid, Chronic, Atypical, BCR-ABL Negative
